title: Esther Banda
text:
Esther Mwila Banda (born 4 November 1958) is a <a href="Zambia">Zambia</a>n former politician. She served as Member of the <a href="National%20Assembly%20%28Zambia%29">National Assembly</a> for <a href="Chililabombwe%20%28Zambian%20National%20Assembly%20constituency%29">Chililabombwe</a> from 2006 until 2016, and was a Deputy Minister between 2011 and 2016.
Biography.
Banda studied for a BA in sociology and worked as a sociologist. She contested the <a href="2001%20Zambian%20general%20election">2001 general elections</a> as the <a href="United%20Party%20for%20National%20Development">United Party for National Development</a> candidate in Chililabombwe, but came second to <a href="Movement%20for%20Multi-Party%20Democracy">Movement for Multi-Party Democracy</a> candidate <a href="Wamundila%20Muliokela">Wamundila Muliokela</a>. In the <a href="2006%20Zambian%20general%20election">2006 general elections</a> Banda was the <a href="Patriotic%20Front%20%28Zambia%29">Patriotic Front</a> candidate and defeated Muliokela (who was then Minister of Defence), becoming the constituency's MP. She was re-elected in the <a href="2011%20Zambian%20general%20election">2011</a>, after which she was appointed <a href="Ministry%20of%20Local%20Government%20%28Zambia%29">Deputy Minister Local Government, Housing, Early Education and Environmental Protection</a>. The following year she became Deputy Minister in the newly created <a href="Ministry%20of%20Gender">Ministry of Gender and Child Development</a>. In February 2015 she became <a href="Ministry%20of%20Tourism%20and%20Arts">Deputy Minister of Tourism and Arts</a> after <a href="Edgar%20Lungu">Edgar Lungu</a> became President. She also held the position of National Women's Chairperson within the Patriotic Front.
Banda did not run in the <a href="2016%20Zambian%20general%20election">2016 general elections</a>, and was succeeded as Chililabombwe MP by the PF candidate <a href="Richard%20Musukwa">Richard Musukwa</a>.
